ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Flaccid Tympanic Membrane / Atelectasis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of high intraoral pressures from trumpet playing, hypercompliant tympanometry (Type Ad), and video otoscopy showing significant TM distension during Valsalva.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Noise-Induced Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Left ear high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss notch (3-8 kHz) consistent with long-term exposure to loud music.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Eustachian Tube Dysfunction
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Underlying mechanism allowing pressure transfer to middle ear, though specific symptoms like autophony (patulous ET) were denied.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Initial evaluation of hearing sensitivity for reported fluctuating loss.
To assess speech reception thresholds and word recognition ability.
To evaluate middle ear function and tympanic membrane compliance.
To assess integrity of the reflex arc and check for conductive pathology.
3-year follow-up to monitor functional speech understanding.
3-year follow-up to monitor middle ear status.
10-year follow-up to monitor middle ear status.
To visualize tympanic membrane movement during Valsalva maneuver.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial evaluation reveals a mixed hearing loss in the right ear with significant air-bone gaps and a high-frequency sensorineural loss in the left ear. Tympanometry indicates a hypercompliant right tympanic membrane (Type Ad), and right acoustic reflexes are absent, consistent with a conductive component likely due to flaccidity from instrument playing.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Left ear normal sloping to mild-moderate SNHL (3-8 kHz). Right ear moderate mixed loss with significant air-bone gaps (250-2000 Hz); RE PTA 38 dB HL, LE PTA 12 dB HL.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRTs agree with PTA (RE 38 dB, LE 12 dB). Word recognition excellent (100%) in both ears.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Normal volume. Right ear static admittance excessively high (1.4 mL) compared to left (0.6 mL), consistent with Type Ad (deep).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Ipsilateral reflex present at 1000 Hz in the left ear, absent in the right ear.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: At the 3-year follow-up, pure-tone thresholds remain stable with persistent air-bone gaps in the right ear. Right ear word recognition has declined slightly. Tympanometry continues to show excessive static admittance in the right ear.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Thresholds similar to initial visit. RE PTA 43 dB HL, LE PTA 10 dB HL. Significant air-bone gaps persist in RE.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: RE WRS decreased to 88% (slight difficulty). LE WRS remains normal (94%).

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: RE static admittance remains excessively high (1.6 mL) compared to left (0.8 mL).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: At the 10-year follow-up, right ear low-frequency thresholds show a slight decrease (5-10 dB). Video otoscopy performed during a Valsalva maneuver confirms severe atelectasis and distension of the right tympanic membrane, explaining the conductive hearing loss.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: LE unchanged. RE low-frequency thresholds decreased by an additional 5-10 dB. RE PTA 43 dB HL.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: RE admittance (0.91 mL) remains higher than left (0.68 mL), though lower than previous visits in this snapshot.

tests.name: Video otoscopy
tests.result_summary: Performed during Valsalva maneuver; showed significant distension of the tympanic membrane into the ear canal.

proposed_items: Mass loading of the tympanic membrane (e.g., blue tack or cigarette paper) as a trial
counseling_actions: Explain that high intraoral pressures from trumpet playing caused the eardrum to become flaccid/stretchy
Discuss that the 'floppiness' of the eardrum causes the conductive hearing loss and fullness
Advise that the left ear high-frequency loss is likely permanent noise damage

escalation.rationale_short: Referral for evaluation of surgical options (tympanoplasty) or medical management of the flaccid tympanic membrane.

follow_up_plan.objective: Determine candidacy for surgery or proceed with hearing aid trial.

expected_outcome: Otological referral was obtained and physical examination was consistent with audiometric and immittance results.
Patient is not enthusiastic about surgical options.
Patient may consider hearing instruments, with a soft band bone-conduction aid for a trial.
